stories.text:
With Facebook taking a lot of heat regarding the negative effects of social media, it made me think of this thought experiment.

Mark Z. decides to prove the positive benefit of using his platform, so he invites 1000+ volunteers with varying skills, resources, locations, etc to swarm around ideas and get stuff done that is a combination of cool, fun, and interesting. It could be online, IRL, or a combination.

You get randomly selected to submit the first project idea to the group. What would you have them do?
stories.title: Ask HN: What would you do with an army of assistants?
Deark: Decode 100s of file formats, converting or extracting contents

stories.text:
I'm a techie; my wife is not. We have a mix of iPhone and Android phones, and Windows PCs. We use Gmail, Facebook, online banking, etc.

I've never found a solution that I can sell to any non-techie family member. 1password and LastPass, Yubikey, etc - while they worked great for me on my PC, they were unusable to my family members whose life revolves around iPhone.

What's the status in 2021? Assuming money is not a concern, what is the best mix of real-world usability for non-techies, and meaningful increase in security? In particular I want to avoid: Account takeovers; password reuse; ignoring security due to obstacles imposed.

Many thanks! :)
stories.title: Ask HN: How to setup meaningful 2FA in 2021
If You Learn to Write, You Can Change Your Life
Mac menu bar app to monitor ETH gas prices
